Plan (EARP) that contains procedures designed to maximize the safety of all employees, contractors, and visitors in the event of an emergency and also guard against environmental consequences.



III.    Facility Identification

The Ajinomoto Windsor, Inc. facility is located at 301 West Third Street in Toluca, Illinois.  Ajinomoto Windsor, Inc. is a producer of frozen Italian foods.  



The NAICS code for the facility is 311412.  A large portion of the facility is refrigerated to preserve products for processing and distribution.   



The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. There are two (2) engine rooms for the refrigeration system onsite that is used for refrigerating coolers, processing rooms, and freezers at the facility. 



The total amount of ammonia in the refrigeration system is approximately 25,800 pounds.  



An aerial map identifying the site location is included as Appendix A. 



IV.    Hazard Assessment - Worse Case Scenarios (WCS)

Appendix B consists of the RMP*Submit Printout and contains additional information on the worst-case scenario.  Appendix C consists of the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the worse case release scenario. 



V.    Hazard Assessment - Alternative Release Scenarios (ARS)

Appendix B consists of the RMP*Submit Printout and contains additional information on the alternative release scenario.  Appendix D consists of the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the alternative release scenario. 



VI.    General Accidental Release Prevention Program

A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program.   



This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. An audit of the PSM and RM Programs were conducted on January 10, 11, a

nd 20, 2017, in compliance with the requirement to conduct audits every three years.  The elements of the PSM / RM Program 3 prevention program and a brief description are listed below.

?    Employee Participation - Ajinomoto Windsor, Inc. has developed a site-specific employee participation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses, standard operating procedures, and other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP regulation.  In addition, the employee participation program will ensure employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  

?    Process Safety Information - Ajinomoto Windsor, Inc. maintains a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained. Process safety information for the ammonia process has been compiled and was last reviewed and updated as of January 2017.

?    Process Hazard Analysis - Ajinomoto Windsor, Inc. has updated a site-specific PHA program that ensures a PHA is conducted initially, at a minimum of every five (5) years, and whenever a change is significant enough to require a change in PSI.  In addition, this program ensures PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and ensures findings and recommendations of PHAs are properly documented. Ajinomoto Windsor, Inc. conducted a thorough PHA study for the refrigeration system during September 2014. 

?    Operating Procedures - Ajinomoto Windsor, Inc. has updated a site-specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operations and ensures they are properly maintained. Annually, the operating procedures will be reviewed and certified as accurate.

?    Training - Ajinomoto Windsor, Inc. has updated a site-specific training procedure t

hat ensures employees operating the ammonia process have the knowledge to safely operate the process, are aware of the potential hazards of the process, and understand the causes of process problems.

?    Management of Change - Ajinomoto Windsor, Inc. has updated a site-specific management of change procedure that ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented.  

?    Pre-Startup Review - Ajinomoto Windsor, Inc. has updated a site-specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures a safety review is performed when modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require a change in PSI.

?    Mechanical Integrity - Ajinomoto Windsor, Inc. has updated a site-specific mechanical integrity procedure that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training.  

?    Contractor Qualifications - Ajinomoto Windsor, Inc. has updated a site-specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employers' safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between the facility and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency response plan and control over entrance into process areas.

?    Incident Investigation - Ajinomoto Windsor, Inc. has updated a site-specific incident investigation procedure that ensures each incident that either results in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  This procedure will also make provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the

conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly addressed.  

?    Compliance Audit - Ajinomoto Windsor, Inc. has updated a site-specific compliance audit program that ensures compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years to verify that the facility's PSM/RMP practices and procedures are adequate and are being followed.  The most recent compliance audit was conducted on January 10, 11, and 20, 2017.   

?    Hot Work Permits - Ajinomoto Windsor, Inc. has updated a best management practice for hot work.  Ajinomoto Windsor, Inc. reviewed their hot work permit procedures for the refrigeration system during January 2017.  



VII.    Five-Year Accident History

The Ajinomoto Windsor, Inc. facility has not experienced any accidental anhydrous ammonia releases, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. 



VIII.    Emergency Response Program

Ajinomoto Windsor, Inc. has developed an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take, and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release.  



Annually, Ajinomoto Windsor, Inc. conducts training for facility employees on proper evacuation procedures and interacts (i.e. onsite inspections) with the Toluca Fire Protection District.  



The facility has coordinated their ERP with the Toluca Fire Protection District.  This coordination effort has included providing the agency with a copy of our ERP, and providing a site diagram and hazardous material information, meeting with Toluca Fire Protection District personnel to discuss the facility's operations/processes, and encouraging periodic on-site inspections and coordination with Toluca Fire Protection District personnel.



 

Ajinomoto Windsor, Inc. has determined that the Toluca Fire Protection District wil

l be utilized for response to all accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia that reach the Immediately Dangerous to Life and Health (IDLH) concentration of 300 parts per million (PPM).  



The facility has strategically placed windsocks on the corners of the facility buildings for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release and evacuation of the building.  



The current Safety Data Sheet (SDS) for anhydrous ammonia is included in Appendix E. 



IX.    Emergency Communications

The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are available onsite.



X.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Chemical safety is an important part of the facility's operations. Ajinomoto Windsor, Inc. is currently implementing their Process Safety Management Program and continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for the facility.   



XI.    Management Program

Ajinomoto Windsor, Inc. has updated a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This system has assigned qualified person(s) (or position) to assist in the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals will be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  Currently, Frank Stoeger, Plant Project Engineer, is responsible for implementation of the overall Risk Management Program.
